title: 109_s2565
content:
The "Vermont Wilderness Act of 2006" is designated as the official title of the Act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Agriculture, and the term "State" refers to the State of Vermont. The Act includes the designation of wilderness areas in Vermont. The Wilderness Act designates wilderness areas in Vermont, including the Glastenbury Wilderness and Joseph Battell Wilderness managed by the US Forest Service. The Wilderness Act designates new wilderness areas in Vermont managed by the US Forest Service: Breadloaf Wilderness (4,223 acres), Lye Brook Wilderness (2,171 acres), and Peru Peak Wilderness (797 acres). The Big Branch Wilderness, comprising 42 acres of Federal land managed by the US Forest Service, is designated as a new wilderness area in Vermont. SEC. 102 of the Act requires the Secretary to file a map and legal description of designated wilderness areas with specific committees. The filed documents have the same legal effect as the Act itself, with the Secretary allowed to correct errors. The maps and descriptions must be available for public inspection. Each wilderness area designated under this section shall be administered by the Secretary in accordance with the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 and the Wilderness Act. State jurisdiction over wildlife and fish on public land is preserved, including stocking fish in lakes, ponds, rivers, and streams. The Forest Service allows the use of minimum tools and traditional methods to mark and maintain trails. The Forest Service permits the use of minimum tools and traditional methods to mark and maintain specific trails, including the Appalachian National Scenic Trail, Long Trail, Catamount Trail, and associated trails and structures. The Secretary may waive requirements for the Catamount Trail in the Lye Brook Wilderness and assist in its relocation and completion. The Association plans to relocate and finish construction of the Catamount Trail with assistance from the Secretary. TITLE II--MOOSALAMOO NATIONAL RECREATION AREA

SEC. 201. DESIGNATION.

Federal land managed by the United States Forest Service, approximately 16,890 acres, designated as the "Moosalamoo National Recreation Area".

SEC. 202. MAP AND DESCRIPTION. SEC. 202. MAP AND DESCRIPTION.

The Secretary must file a map and legal description of the national recreation area with specific committees, and these documents will have the same legal force as if included in the Act. The map and description will be available for public inspection in the Forest Service Chief's office. SEC. 203. ADMINISTRATION OF NATIONAL RECREATION AREA. The Secretary shall administer the Moosalamoo National Recreation Area in accordance with laws applicable to National Forest System units and the objectives specified in the Green Mountain National Forest Land and Resource Management Plan for multiple use management, educational opportunities, public enjoyment, and resource value management. The Secretary shall develop a comprehensive management plan for the Moosalamoo National Recreation Area to manage resource values without impairing public recreation values and special attributes. This plan does not affect the State's jurisdiction over wildlife and fish on public land. The Secretary can still manage the Green Mountain Escarpment Management Area and Ecological Special Areas as described in the Green Mountain National Forest Land and Resource Management Plan. The Secretary must develop a comprehensive management plan for the Moosalamoo National Recreation Area, involving public participation and considering input from various agencies, organizations, and individuals. The plan must be submitted to specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate.
